title: 113_s911
content:
The Act titled "Emergency Transportation Safety Fund Act" establishes and funds incentives for reinvesting foreign earnings in the United States. The Act establishes a 5 percent tax rate for repatriation under section 965 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It also allows taxpayers to elect repatriation by the due date for filing their tax return. Repatriation includes current and accumulated foreign earnings. The Act establishes a 5 percent tax rate for repatriation under section 965 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, allowing taxpayers to elect repatriation by the due date for filing their tax return. Repatriation includes current and accumulated foreign earnings without diminution by distributions made during the election year for all controlled foreign corporations of the United States shareholder. Conforming amendments are made to sections 965(b) and 965(c) of the Code. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years ending after the enactment of this Act, treating all United States shareholders in an affiliated group filing a consolidated return as one shareholder. Clerical amendments are made to section 965 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Establishment of Emergency Transportation Safety Fund. Established in the Treasury of the United States is the "Emergency Transportation Safety Fund" to receive appropriations equivalent to 50 percent of taxes on eligible 965 dividends received by US corporations, minus the foreign tax credit allowed under the Internal Revenue Code. Definitions for this subsection include "eligible 965 dividend" as amounts received from controlled foreign corporations with a deduction under section 965 of the Internal Revenue Code, and "non-deductible portion" as the excess over the deductible portion. Additionally, emergency relief expenditures are addressed in an amendment to Section 125(c) of title 23, United States Code. The United States Code is amended to include the establishment of the Emergency Transportation Safety Fund for prioritized projects meeting eligibility requirements. TITLE II--EMERGENCY TRANSPORTATION SAFETY PRIORITY LIST

SEC. 201. EMERGENCY TRANSPORTATION PRIORITIES. The Secretary of Transportation, with input from State and local officials, will create a prioritized list of emergency transportation projects for funding allocation. Criteria for ranking projects include being part of the interstate highway system, closed for safety reasons, impact on interstate commerce, traffic volume, and overall project value. A report on the list must be submitted within 120 days. The Secretary of Transportation will submit a report to Congress within 120 days, listing emergency transportation projects to be funded through the Emergency Transportation Safety Fund. Quarterly updates will be provided, including criteria used for project prioritization.
